newsitem.title: POLAND: WORLD BANK MAY CREDIT POLISH TOWN INFRASTRUCTURE.
newsitem.headline: WORLD BANK MAY CREDIT POLISH TOWN INFRASTRUCTURE.

text.p: The World Bank may help Polish towns further develop their infrastructure, World Bank President James D. Wolfensohn said.
"In the foreseeable future local Polish municipalities may become sizeable recipients of World Bank credits," he told a news conference in the southern city of Krakow.
"To facilitate the flow of resources, the Polish government plans to set up an Agency for Municipal Development which will be our parnter in negotiating credit terms," he added.

Wolfensohn said the World Bank might provide credits to help Krakow build a waste-treatment plant, adapt rails lines for urban transport and participate in the creation of the Krakow High Technology Centre.
The city would first have to formally apply for such assistance, he added.
